CHAPTER xxm-ot inquisitions and the testimony of Turks.

Two direct questions arise in this case: l 1) When may torture be used to ascertain the truth, and (a) what weight should be given to the testimony offered by Turks? Slave witnesses may not be tortured, it the question is one of money only, and it the truth can be ascertained otherwise. Freemen may be tortured only when they are charged as accomplices, and give inconsistent evidence. The matter is left to the discretiori of the magistrate. So far as the second point goes, the testimony ot Turks is not accepted against Christians. In addition to the two direct questions just mentioned, two points are indirectly involved in the case.
